SUMMARY: HyfR , hydrogenase four regulator, controls expression of genes responsible for proton-translocating formate hydrogenase system and for formate transport under anaerobiosis, low pH, and post-exponential growth conditions [9387241]. As a member of group of σ54-dependent transcriptional regulators, HyfR contains three domains: sensory domain, located in N terminus; central domain, involved in open complex formation, ATP hydrolysis, and interaction with σ54, and C-terminal domain, which contains a helix-turn-helix motif for DNA binding [9387241]. An iron-sulfur cluster and a metal cofactor (possibly a similar metal or formate) have been proposed as signals sensed by HyfR [12426353]. HyfR shows 46% identity to FhlA, a member of same group. se proteins are dissimilar in ir N-terminal regions, which in FhlA recognizes formate. However, y show only one different residue in ir helix-turn-helix motif, suggesting that y recognize similar DNA-binding sites [9387241]. HyfR protein is autoregulated. gene that codes for it is 11th in hyf operon, which contains 12 genes that are not expressed at significant levels. This operon is induced under anaerobiosis, at low pH, and under fermentative conditions by formate, and it is subject to catabolite repression [14702328, 12426353].
